facts.text: Bhagwandas and Netram are two brothers

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwandas and Netram are two brothers who along with Mt. Rameshwari, a daughter of the former,

facts.text: Mt. Rameshwari is a daughter of Bhagwandas

anchor.surface_text: who along with Mt. Rameshwari, a daughter of the former,

facts.text: Bhagwandas, Netram and Mt. Rameshwari tried by Sessions Judge of Ganganagar under s. 302 IPC and acquitted

anchor.surface_text: were tried by the Sessions Judge of Ganganagar for an offence under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code but were acquitted.

facts.text: High Court of Rajasthan reversed acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram, convicted under s. 302/34, sentenced to transportation for life

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court of Rajasthan, the order of acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram was reversed and they were companyvicted under s. 302 read with s. 34 and sentenced to transportation for life.

facts.text: High Court affirmed acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari

anchor.surface_text: The order as to Mt. Rameshwari was affirmed and she was acquitted.

facts.text: Convicted persons obtained Special Leave to appeal under Art. 136

anchor.surface_text: The companyvicted persons have obtained Special Leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Canal restarted flowing on May 5, 1953

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution the canal after a temporary closure restarted flowing on May 5, 1953.

facts.text: Shivlal allowed to take water though not his turn

anchor.surface_text: And although it was number his turn of water the deceased Shivlal was allowed to take the water to irrigate his fields.

facts.text: On May 6 canal full, Shivlal's turn 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. 6 hours, watered till 10-30 a.m. to fill empty village diggi

anchor.surface_text: On May 6 the canal was flowing to its full capacity and Shivlal was to take his turn of water which was of 6 hours duration from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. but he watered his lands from 8 a.m. to 10-30 a.m. because the village diggi  pond  which was empty had to be filled up.

facts.text: Mirab Ram Karan PW1 with consent of Shivlal diverted water to fill diggi, promised rest 3.5 hours later

anchor.surface_text: Mirab Ram Karan P.W. 1 with the companysent of Shivlal diverted the water for the purpose of filling up the diggi, promising him  Shivlal  to get him the rest of his turn of water, i.e. for 3 1/2 hours after the diggi had been filled up.

facts.text: Diggi filled up by 1 p.m. on the 7th

anchor.surface_text: The diggi was filled up by 1 p.m. on the 7th.

facts.text: Bhagwandas prevented Shivlal from diverting water to his field, claiming it his turn

anchor.surface_text: Shivlal then wanted to divert the water into his field but Bhagwandas prevented him from doing so claiming the turn to be his.

facts.text: According to Ram Karan Mirab PW1, Bhagwandas turn after Surta next to Shivlal

anchor.surface_text: According to Ram Karan Mirab P.W. 1 the turn of Bhagwandas was after Surta whose turn was next to that of Shivlal.

facts.text: Bhagwandas hit Shivlal on head with kassi after shouting enemy was going

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwandas thereupon shouted that the enemy was going and hit Shivlal on the head with a kassi.

facts.text: Netram hit Shivlal with lathi, Shivlal fell, both beat him

anchor.surface_text: Netram then hit Shivlal with lathi as a result of which he fell down and then both beat Shivlal,

facts.text: Mt. Rameshwari allegedly joined beating with wooden handle of kassi

anchor.surface_text: and Mt. Rameshwari also, it was alleged, joined in this beating with a wooden handle of a kassi.

facts.text: Occurrence witnessed by Hazari PW3 grazing camels in field of Surta

anchor.surface_text: This occurrence was witnessed by Hazari P.W. 3 who was grazing his camels in the field of Surta.

facts.text: Shivlal died on 8th at 8-15 a.m.

anchor.surface_text: but died the following day  8th  at 8-15 a.m.

facts.text: FIR recorded on May 7 at 7-30 p.m. based on Ex. P-1 by Ram Pratap s/o Shivlal

anchor.surface_text: The First Information Report was based on a written report Ex. P-1 by Ram Pratap s o Shivlal. It was recorded on May 7 at about 7-30 p.m.

facts.text: Shivlal had 15 injuries, injury No.1 sharp-edged, No.2 blunt, both grievous and fatal

anchor.surface_text: He had 15 injuries on his body, out of which injury No. 1 was with a sharp-edged weapon and injury No. 2 with a blunt weapon and both these injuries were grievous and were individually and companylectively fatal sufficient to cause death.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted the accused disbelieving prosecution evidence

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge disbelieved the whole evidence and acquitted the accused.

facts.text: High Court accepted testimony of Hazari PW3

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge described Hazari as a facile fluent liar but his testimony was accepted by the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds evidence insufficient to convict

anchor.surface_text: In our view the evidence in the present case is of such quality and numberlegitimate inference of guilt of the accused companyld properly be drawn.

facts.text: No compelling reasons for High Court to reverse acquittal

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the High Court does number disclose any such reasons justifying interference with the findings of the trial Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absent reliable eye-witness like Hazari, dying declarations with infirmities and contradictions cannot sustain conviction without corroboration

holdings.text: This Court in Sundarlal v. The State of Madhya Pradesh disapproved of Judges drawing conclusions adverse to the accused by relying upon such passages in the absence of their being put to medical witnesses
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in discrediting doctor's evidence using medical books by Modi and Lyon without putting relevant passages to the doctor PW11

holdings.text: where the evidence is such that no Tribunal could legitimately infer from it that the accused is guilty this Court would set aside the conviction
holdings.reasoning_summary: Eyewitness Hazari unreliable due to contradictions and tutoring implication; dying declarations infirm; medical evidence improperly assessed; kassi recovery neutral; overall evidence insufficient citing Stephen Seneviratne

holdings.text: the High Court should not set aside an acquittal unless there are substantial and compelling reasons for doing so
holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle reiterated from prior Supreme Court cases including Surajpal Singh, Ajmer Singh, Aher Raja Khima
